docs.lead_paragraph: FOR many doctors like Dr. Philip Heinegg, the advent of managed care has been a mixed blessing. As a family practitioner, he has become the newly respected gatekeeper to an increasingly complex maze of insurance companies and medical providers -- the first stop for most patients before they see a specialist. But at times Dr. Heinegg feels as if he is being inundated with forms, procedures and a seemingly infinite number of requirements that interfere with the business of healing. ''Every stick has two ends,'' said Dr. Heinegg, 46, whose office is in Larchmont, whose medical skills were learned at the knee of his father, a country doctor who had no insurance providers to dictate how many bushels of New York apples were proper payment for his services.
docs.abstract: Dr Philip Heinegg, family practitioner in Larchmont, NY, commenting on pros and cons of managed health care, focuses on myriad forms, procedures and rules that interfere with medical care; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the largest expansion of government-paid health insurance since the formation of Medicaid 32 years ago, states say they will soon be providing free or low-cost health care to at least half the nation's 10 million uninsured children. Spurred by last year's overhaul of the welfare system, which will leave many recipients without health coverage as they move into jobs, and now by a new Federal law that will pay for most of the care, states like New York, Florida, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Wisconsin and Arkansas have already begun child insurance programs that have become models for other states.

headline.main: States to Give More Children Health Coverage

docs.abstract: States, spurred by 1996 overhaul of welfare system and new Federal law that will provide health care for poor, will provide free or low-cost health care to at least half of nation's uninsured children in largest expansion of government-paid health insurance since formation of Medicaid 32 years ago; of 10 million uninsured children nationwide, 7.1 million are in families Government considers hard core of working poor whose incomes are less than 200 percent of Federal poverty line, disqualifying them from receiving welfare and free health care through Federal Medicaid program; most states are devising plans that would move families into managed care systems in which most workers take part; say biggest obstacle is negotiating design of programs with Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which is carrying out new law; are concerned about locating uninsured children and persuading parents to enroll them with doctors and clinics; children's advocacy groups warn of possible abuses; say employers who currently cover most of their workers' insurance may terminate coverage, leaving responsibility to states (M)
docs.snippet: In the largest expansion of government-paid health insurance since the formation of Medicaid 32 years ago, states say they will soon be providing free or low-cost health care to at least half the nation's 10 million uninsured children.     Spurred by...

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that open positions on short sales fell modestly in the last month, to 3.35 billion shares, a decline of about five-tenths of 1 percent for trades in the month ended Sept. 10 and settled on Sept. 15. On the American Stock Exchange, short interest rose to record levels, up 3.3 percent, to 182.28 million shares during the period.

headline.main: Big Board Reports a Drop In Uncovered Short Sales

docs.abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports open positions on short sales fell to 3.35 billion shares in month ended Sept 10, down 0.5 percent; American Stock Exchange reports short interest rose to record 182.28 million shares in period, up 3.3 percent; tables (S)2

docs.lead_paragraph: As clients of two of the nation's largest accounting firms absorbed the news of a pending merger, perhaps nowhere is the consternation greater than at those companies that have recently switched from one firm to the other. Having chosen firmly between Coopers & Lybrand or Price Waterhouse, taking into account how much they charge, the personalities of the partners and their contrasting approach to looking over the books, these companies now find that decision undone. Take Oregon Steel Mills Inc., a company in Portland, Ore., that dumped Coopers & Lybrand as its auditor in July 1996. In addition to finding a new auditor, which happened to be Price Waterhouse, Oregon Steel filed a lawsuit against Coopers & Lybrand. Now the company is faced with the prospect of doing business with Coopers again through the combined firm. ''So I prefer not to say anything,'' said L. Ray Adams, the company's chief financial officer. It is safe to say, however, that the audit could be up for grabs.

headline.main: Merger Plan By Audit Firms Puts Ex-Clients In a Quandary

docs.abstract: Planned merger of Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse accounting firms creates dilemma for companies who have recently switched from one firm to other; Coopers has picked up some 27 Price Waterhouse clients and Price Waterhouse some 29 former Coopers clients since 1992 (M)
docs.snippet: As clients of two of the nation's largest accounting firms absorbed the news of a pending merger, perhaps nowhere is the consternation greater than at those companies that have recently switched from one firm to the other. Having chosen firmly...

docs.lead_paragraph: For years Long Island's police officers have been among the nation's best compensated, with high salaries, short work schedules and generous fringe benefits. The resulting costs have imposed an increasing burden on local taxpayers, and the issue is now provoking public debate.

headline.main: On Long Island, Critics Upset About the High Cost of Police

docs.abstract: High cost of police on Long Island, a major burden on taxpayers, is provoking public debate, with critics assailing police compensation as out of control; for years Long Island's police officers have been among nation's best compensated, with high salaries, short work schedules and generous fringe benefits; in Nassau, police budget accounts for 72 percent of proposed property tax levy in County Exec Thomas S Gulotta's budget for 1998; in neighboring Suffolk, 79 percent of county property tax is designated for police; police costs on Long Island will increase under latest labor contracts; base pay for experienced Nassau officer will rise to $73,859 in year 2000; but total cost--with overtime and benefits--will reach $120,000; chart compares Nassau and Suffolk police salaries with those in Westchester County, White Plains, Stamford, Conn, Chicago, Los Angeles and New York City (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of his 40th birthday last summer, Harold Dusenbury, a black electrician, ambled down Eighth Street in the Village on his way to work at a Kmart construction site. He wore a T-shirt and dungarees and carried a toolbox. At that moment, unknown to him, a police radio was repeatedly broadcasting the description of a fleeing suspect: ''black male in T-shirt and jeans.''

headline.main: A Police Mistake, an Injured Man, But No Charges Against Officers

docs.abstract: Manhattan Dist Atty Robert Morgenthau closes year-long investigation into case of Harold Dusenbury, black man who suffered serious injuries after he was wrongfully detained by police, without filing criminal charges against officers; Daniel J Castleman, chief of investigations for District Attorney, says use of force during arrest does not justify criminal prosecution just because officer mistakenly arrested wrong person; Dusenbury has filed Federal suit against New York City alleging that his civil rights were violated; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The mystery at the core of ''Miracle Mile,'' Clark Middleton's graceful, affecting monologue about his lifelong struggle with a physically debilitating illness, is: Why does someone with a disfiguring condition subject himself to the trials of public display? In the daring and stillness with which Mr. Middleton holds a stage, an explanation comes into focus. The actor is afflicted both by the tormenting legacy of his painful childhood disability, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, and a contradictory urge that can be just as tenacious: the need to perform.

headline.main: Into the Spotlight With a Disability

docs.abstract: Peter Marks reviews performance of Clark Middleton in his one-man play, Miracle Mile, at Theater Row Theater; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Tiananmen Square Letter Challenges the Party Line A letter circulated at the Communist Party Congress in Beijing urging delegates to challenge the party's official interpretation of the Tiananmen Square massacre as the putting down of a ''counter-revolutionary rebellion.'' The letter, whose veracity could not be confirmed, was signed by Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief just prior to the 1989 massacre and sided with the students. The letter was also printed in full in a Hong Kong newspaper. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration has terminated the contract for a vast new Medicare computer system that had been promoted as a way to speed payment of claims, improve customer service and combat fraud in Medicare, the nation's largest health insurance program, officials said today. GTE, the main contractor, had been hired to consolidate and modernize Medicare's far-flung computer systems. But those systems were so antiquated and complicated that they thwarted the company's efforts.

headline.main: Medicare Overhaul Is Halted, Bogging Down in Complexity

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration terminates contract for vast new Medicare computer system that had been promoted as way to speed payment of claims, improve customer service and combat fraud; efforts by GTE, main contractor, to consolidate and modernize program's far-flung computer systems, has been thwarted because system's age and complexity; Federal officials say job was far more complicated that anticipated, in part because they did not know exactly what current system, run by 72 private insurance companies nationwide, was acutally doing; say project is behind schedule, over budget and plagued with problems; will try more gradual approach, working on individual pieces of system, rather than tackling entire project at once (M)
docs.snippet: The Clinton Administration has terminated the contract for a vast new Medicare computer system that had been promoted as a way to speed payment of claims, improve customer service and combat fraud in Medicare, the nation's largest health insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, today proposed an election-year budget that would cut county property taxes by about 5 percent, or between $17 and $26 for a typical homeowner. His Democratic challenger, Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay, immediately attacked the budget proposal as fiscal gimmickry.

headline.main: Nassau Chief Wants to Cut Property Tax By 5 Percent
